Program Description  This is the second subprogram of the Assam Governance and Public 
Resource  Management  Sector  Development  Program  (AGPRM). 
Subprogram I of the AGPRM was successfully implemented by the 
government of Assam from 2005 to 2007. Subprogram II consists of 
a  loan  of  $100  million,  to  be  implemented  over  3  years,  and  a 
technical assistance (TA) grant of $600,000, for capacity building 
and for supporting program implementation. 
   
Rationale  In the 1990s, the government of Assam faced fiscal and governance-
related  structural  problems.  Its  weak  fiscal  position  was  due  to 
stagnation  of  tax  and  nontax  revenue  and  growing  recurrent 
expenditure. The government also suffered from rising expenditure, 
pension liabilities, and fiscal drain caused by large subsidies to loss-
making public sector enterprises (PSEs).  
 
Under subprogram I of the AGPRM, however, various reforms were 
undertaken by the government of Assam to improve governance and 
better manage available resources. Through fiscal reforms, which 
include approval of a medium-term fiscal plan and introduction of the 
Fiscal Responsibility and Budgetary Management Act, the profile of 
fiscal imbalances has been improved and a large revenue deficit has 
been converted into a surplus in recent years. This was achieved 
through  a  combination  of  revenue  augmentation,  a  reduction  in 
revenue losses, and closer monitoring and control of expenditure. 
 
   
In accordance with the AGPRM and following the reforms under 
subprogram I, subprogram II is targeted at (i) strengthening revenue 
administration through capacity development and implementation of

ii   
information and communication technology systems, (ii) improving 
expenditure  management  through  the  gradual  introduction  of 
outcome-based  budgeting  and  improvements  in  operation  and 
maintenance expenditure estimating, (iii) developing a centralized 
debt management system to include contingent liabilities, and (iv) 
undertaking  further  PSE  closures  and  related  compensation  and 
labor rehabilitation. Reforms under subprogram II will allow greater 
fiscal space, thus enabling the government of Assam to allocate 
more  fiscal  resources  to  much-needed  social  and  economic 
infrastructure. This will, in turn, promote private sector investment, 
thus leading to income generation and higher employment.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  subprogram  II  is  to  achieve  improved  financial 
flexibility for the government of Assam so it is able to more actively 
promote social and physical infrastructure development and improve 
economic  growth  performance.  This  will  lead  to  a  reduction  in 
poverty  in  the  state  through  better  fiscal  management  and 
governance. The outcomes of subprogram II are (i) increased tax 
buoyancy via strengthened revenue administration; (ii) expenditure 
reoriented  to  allow  for  greater  allocation  for  investments  in,  and 
maintenance of, assets; (iii) more efficient debt servicing through 
improved  debt  management  policy  and  procedures  and  a 
strengthened debt management unit; and (iv) accelerated closure of 
PSEs  and  implementation  of  related  compensation  and  labor 
rehabilitation. 
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $100 million equivalent from the ordinary capital resources 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be provided under ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The 
loan will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 3 years, an 
interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based 
lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and such 
other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement.  
 
The Government of India will relend the local currency generated 
from the proceeds of the loan to the government of Assam. The 
relending will be in accordance with the Government’s arrangement 
for transfer of external assistance to the government of Assam and it 
will  be  treated  as  additional  to  the  central  government  transfers 
allocated annually to the state of Assam.  
   
Program Period  Subprogram II is estimated to be completed by September 2011.

fulfillment of all agreed conditions for the first tranche and following 
effectiveness of the loan. The second tranche will be released upon

will be released upon fulfillment of all agreed conditions for the third

release.   
   
Executing Agency  The  executing  agency  for  subprogram  II  will  be  the  Finance 
Department of the government of Assam.  
   
Implementation  A  program  steering  committee  will  be  responsible  for  overall 
Arrangements  coordination, implementation, and monitoring of subprogram II. The 
committee, to be chaired by a senior official not below the rank of the 
principal  secretary  of  the  government  of  Assam,  will  include  all 
secretaries of participating departments.  
 
The fiscal management unit in the Finance Department established 
under subprogram I will continue to undertake fiscal management 
reforms and be responsible for daily implementation of subprogram II 
under the guidance of the program steering committee. The fiscal 
management unit will coordinate with ADB and various stakeholders 
and will solicit feedback from experts from within and outside the 
government of Assam on a regular basis.  
   
Procurement and  The proceeds of the program loan will be used to finance the foreign 
Disbursement  exchange costs (excluding local taxes and duties) of items produced 
in and procured from ADB member countries, excluding ineligible 
items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral 
sources. In accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of 
Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program 
Loans (1998), the proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed to 
the Borrower.  
   
Program Benefits   The benefits of subprogram II are expected to be evident in the 
following: (i) the availability of more resources to invest in social and 
economic infrastructure which should ultimately assist in enhancing 
the welfare of the poor in the rural hinterlands, (ii) more efficient 
allocation of budget resources based on outcomes sought rather 
than on an input-based system, and (iii) the ability of the government 
of Assam, in the long term, to place its fiscal affairs on a sounder 
footing that can sustain investments for more rapid and inclusive 
growth.  
   
Risks and  The  success  of  subprogram  II  depends  on  the  government  of 
Assumptions  Assam’s continuing strong commitment to fiscal reforms and to the 
broader  governance  issues  of  transparency  in  fiscal  matters. 
However, the possibility remains that current measures and reform 
efforts,  including  insufficient  capacity  in  specific  implementing 
government agencies to carry out the reforms, may not be sustained. 
These risks will be mitigated by (i) continued policy dialogue with the 
government of Assam and other stakeholders in Assam (such as 
business  associations),  and  (ii)  specific  technical  assistance  and 
capacity-development  support  and  follow-up  aimed  at  the  weak 
implementing agencies. For its part, the government of Assam has 
publicly  and  officially  (i.e.,  in  the  budget  speech)  expressed  its

iv   
commitment to pursue the reforms sought under subprogram II, and 
the  level  of  engagement  in  the  program  design  has  been 
substantive. 
 
The  assumptions  inherent  in  subprogram  II  are  that  (i)  the 
government of Assam commitment to reforms across the various 
sectors  (including  PSEs)  will  remain  high  during  the  program 
implementation period, (ii) existing central policies that are favorable 
to  the  government  of  Assam  will  continue  to  be  in  place  in  the 
medium  to  long  term,  (iii)  the  greater  fiscal  space  will  result  in 
reorientation of expenditure into social and economic infrastructure, 
and (iv) any political developments that take place in the short-to-
medium  term  do  not  adversely  affect  subprogram  II  in  any 
substantive manner.  
   
Technical Assistance  The TA will support the key government of Assam agencies that are 
implementing  subprogram  II.  The  TA  will  also  mitigate  the  risks 
associated  with  insufficient  capacity  in  these  agencies.  The 
estimated cost of the TA program is $750,000, of which $600,000 will 
be a grant from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government 
of  Japan,  and  $150,000  will  be  provided  by  the  government  of 
Assam as in-kind support. Consultants for the TA will be recruited 
according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time).

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to India for the second subprogram (subprogram II) of the Assam Governance and Public 
Resource Management Sector Development Program (AGPRM). The report also describes 
proposed technical assistance (TA) for supporting subprogram II of the AGPRM. If the Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will 
approve the TA. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
 
2.  Recent  Economic  Performance  in  India. The Indian economy continues to show 
impressive growth with strong macroeconomic fundamentals. Since January 2005 the economy 
has recorded a growth rate of over 8% in 12 successive quarters up to the end of December 
2007.  According  to  latest  estimates,  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  at  8.7%  during 
FY2007. Average annual growth achieved during the Tenth Five-Year Plan period (2002–2007) 
was 7.8%, the highest ever in any plan period. With respect to fiscal management, the tax–GDP 
ratio increased from 9.2% in FY2003 to 12.4% in FY2007. The Government of India continued 
progress in terms of reduction of revenue deficit and fiscal deficit, and increase in the outlays for 
several social sector and infrastructure development programs. However, the inflation rate in 
mid-2008 has crossed to 11% and the Indian economy is showing signs of slowing, and this 
may have a negative impact on the collection of revenue at the central government level. 
Poverty reduction and social development through inclusive growth is the central goal of the 
11th Five-Year Plan (2007–2012), which rightly recognizes that the growth process cannot be 
sustained or made more inclusive without the supporting physical and social infrastructure. 
 
3.  Development in Assam. Assam is the largest of the seven states in northeastern India.1 
It has 2.5% (or 26.7 million) of India’s population spread over 2.4% of the country’s area. 
Assam’s  development  is  of  particular  significance  as  a  gateway  for  development  of  the 
northeast  given  both  its  relative  size  and  its  position  as  a  center  of  interstate  trade  and 
integrated  infrastructure  in  the  northeast.  Several  structural  features  have  historically 
constrained the economic performance of Assam. Its problems have been those of remoteness, 
partially hilly terrain, and high transportation costs. Assam is also constrained by high population 
density, a large but slow-growing agriculture sector, and a high incidence of poverty. In addition, 
insurgency considerably slowed economic activity in the 1990s. All these factors contributed to 
Assam’s gross state domestic product (GSDP) growth rate trend at constant prices during 
FY1993–FY1999 remaining below 2%. With the decline in insurgency in recent years, and some 
strong tax incentives introduced by the central government, the manufacturing and services 
sectors showed buoyant growth during FY1999–FY2005, with manufacturing growing at 8.6% 
per annum and services growing by 8.0%. Led by these growth figures, the GSDP trend growth 
rate has risen to 5.4% during FY1994–FY2006.2 However, due to potential slowing down of the

4.  Against the background of the poor performance of the state economy during the 1990s, 
the finances of the government of Assam underwent a major crisis in the late 1990s with 
revenue deficit and fiscal deficit reaching alarming levels.3 The government of Assam finances 
have showed a steep deterioration since FY1999. With respect to a profile of fiscal imbalance 
relative to GSDP, in FY1999, revenue deficit relative to GSDP rose to 3.4% of GSDP from the 
position of a surplus in the 3 preceding years. Revenue deficit continued until FY2004. The 
fiscal deficit was close to 5% of GSDP in FY2001 and remained high until FY2004. It was due to 
a substantial increase in central transfers and several reform initiatives of the government of 
Assam—including improved expenditure management measures—that a revenue surplus and 
even a fiscal surplus were recorded in FY2005 and in FY2006. However, a fiscal deficit was 
recorded again in FY2007 despite a surplus in the revenue account. The reemergence of fiscal 
deficit in FY2007 was primarily attributed to a sharp increase in government investment. The 
debt–GSDP ratio of 30% in FY2007 remained higher than the overall benchmark for the debt–
GSDP ratio of 28% prescribed by the Twelfth Finance Commission (TFC).4   
 
III.  THE SECTOR 
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
 
5.  Introduction. In explaining the development of the fiscal crisis in the late 1990s, it is 
notable that Assam's finances were exposed to at least four external shocks beyond the control 
of the government of Assam. Firstly, there was the revision of salaries and pensions of central 
government  employees  and  the  subsequent  near-convergence  of  pay  scales  and  other 
allowances between the center and the states, including Assam. Secondly, there was a fall in 
the central tax–gross domestic product (GDP) ratio by nearly two percentage points during the 
1990s, leading to a fall in the government of Assam’s share of central taxes.5 Thirdly, revenue 
from  forests  in  Assam,  which  at  one  time  was  a  mainstay  of  Assam's  nontax  resources, 
deteriorated  sharply  after  the  Supreme  Court  judgment  banning  unplanned  felling  of  trees 
unless done according to scientific plans. Fourthly, interest rates have risen sharply since the 
mid-1990s, especially on small savings and central loans. These external pressures worked in 
combination with critical internal weaknesses, which emanated from (i) a rise of insurgency 
affecting economic as well as fiscal performance, (ii) subdued industrial growth, (iii) the dismal 
performance  of  public  sector  enterprises  (PSEs),  and  (iv)  a  high  salary  burden  linked  to 
excessive employment in the government of Assam. The basic mismatch in Assam's fiscal 
position  was  reflected in  its  perennial  dependence  on  the  ways  and  means  advance  (the 
resources available to meet expenses) to get through its cash-crisis problem.6

6.  However,  fiscal  reforms  have  since  been  initiated  pursuant  to  the  ADB  Assam 
Governance  and  Public  Resource  Management  Sector  Development  Program  (AGPRM).7 
Under subprogram I of the AGPRM, reforms have led to fiscal recovery with manageable 
deficits as a result of actions on debt restructuring and settlement, PSE closure, tax policy, and 
administrative measures. The government of Assam is no longer resorting to ways and means 
advances and does not run an overdraft with the Reserve Bank of India. Moreover, various 
reforms have been undertaken by the government of Assam during the subprogram I period to 
improve governance and better manage the resources available. As part of other revenue 
augmentation reforms, in order to strengthen weaknesses in revenue collection (value-added 
tax [VAT], excise duty, motor vehicle tax, and forest produce levies), subprogram I undertook 
strengthening  of  checkposts  at  the  main  entry  and  exit  points  on  the  trading  routes  with 
neighboring  states  and  initiated  the  establishment  of  a  composite  computerized  database. 
Furthermore, controls on budget and expenditure management have been improved to enhance 
the efficiency and effectiveness of budget processing.8 Moreover, closure of nine PSEs and two 
units of the Assam Small Industries Development Corporation was notified, and 50% of the 
required disbursement for the voluntary retirement scheme (VRS) has been paid to employees 
of PSEs identified for closure. Part of the explanation for the recovery is the effect of external 
influences. The reason for the improvement in FY2005 and in FY2006 was the increase in 
central fiscal transfers as directed by the recommendations of the TFC. This was combined with 
much higher central tax buoyancy, which helped increase the resource transfers from the center 
and, consequently, a revenue surplus was recorded in FY2005 after a long period of deficits. 
More details have been provided in Appendix 2. 
 
7.  Fiscal Performance. After considerable deterioration in the profile of fiscal imbalances, 
government finances in Assam, as shown in the levels of revenue and fiscal deficits towards the 
latter part of the 1990s, have been recovering since FY2001. A revenue deficit of 2.64% of 
GSDP in FY2001 was converted into a surplus of 1.2% of GSDP as per FY2007 revised 
estimates.9 The fiscal deficit–GSDP ratio has also been reduced from 4.33% in FY2001 to a 
surplus of 1.09% in FY2006 and is well below permissible levels under the government of 
Assam’s Fiscal Responsibility and Budgetary Management (FRBM) Act10 (Appendix 3).  
 
8.  These changes are due to a combination of external and internal factors. The upsurge in 
the GSDP growth rate to levels close to 9% since FY2003, accompanied by an increase in the 
buoyancy of central direct taxes, has been beneficial to Assam’s fiscal profile. Not only has 
there been a corresponding growth in the government of Assam’s share of central taxes, but 
both non-plan and plan grants have also been substantially increased. Also, nominal interest 
rates have declined substantially in the current decade. The debt swap initiatives in the earlier 
part of this decade, and subsequently the substantial debt relief given by the TFC effective from 
FY2005, have resulted in a reduction in the effective interest rate from 10.2% in FY1999 to 8.5%

9.  Factors within Assam have been equally important in improving the financial position of 
the government of Assam. Among the several initiatives taken by the government of Assam, 
some of the important ones relate to the enactment of the FRBM Act and sustained sales tax 
reforms leading up to the introduction of VAT. Assam’s GSDP trend growth rate also picked up 
from less than 2% per annum during FY1993–FY1999 on a trend basis to 5.4% during FY1999 
and FY2005. Own-revenue receipts have also increased from 6.15% in FY2001 to 8.2% of 
GSDP in FY2006 despite a marginal fall in sales tax and VAT collection from 4.8% of GSDP in 
FY2004 to 4.27% in FY2006, due to the change from sales tax to VAT in FY2005.11  
  
10.  The government of Assam has also been successful in containing the growth of revenue 
(recurrent) expenditure due to the earlier mentioned factors of debt consolidation, swaps and 
retirement, and a virtual freeze on recruitments. There has been a decline in the revenue 
expenditure–GSDP ratio from 20% in FY2000 to 18% in FY2006. More importantly, the share of 
salaries in revenue expenditure declined sharply from 60% to about 40% over the same period. 
 
11.  Considerable reforms have also been undertaken to put in order the affairs of the state 
PSEs. Eight PSEs were notified for closure under subprogram I of the AGPRM. In addition, the 
government  of  Assam  identified  both  the  Assam  State  Electricity  Board  and  Assam  State 
Transport Corporation—the two largest loss-generating enterprises—for reform and operational 
restructuring. There has been staff rationalization and public–private partnership initiatives in the 
Assam State Transport Corporation; the Assam State Electricity Board is in the process of being 
unbundled and corporatized. 
 
12.  The results of all these efforts and changes are reflected in a reduction of the revenue 
deficit from the peak of 3.4% of GSDP to less than 1% by FY2004, and a revenue surplus in the 
subsequent years up to FY2007 (revised estimate). The challenges for the government of 
Assam are to sustain this trend and achieve at least a balance on the revenue account by 
FY2008 to meet the FRBM Act targets. The sustainability of the recent fiscal performance 
requires continued emphasis on some areas as described in the following paragraphs. The 
current  achievements  in  fiscal  performance  are  due  to  one-time  corrections,12 and  the 
advantages accruing from these corrections could be lost if fiscal prudence is not maintained, or 
through exposure to risks such as spikes in salaries due to implementation of salary increases 
following the Sixth Pay Commission recommendations. 
 
13.  Central  Transfers.  It  was  due  to  a  substantial  increase  in  fiscal  transfers  that,  in 
FY2005, a revenue surplus and even a small fiscal surplus were recorded. However, formula-
based fiscal transfers to the states depend on the nominal national GDP growth rate. Any 
decline in the growth rate will have an adverse impact on transfers to the states. Given Assam’s 
dependence on central transfers, this has the potential to destabilize fiscal consolidation. Thus, 
mobilizing higher revenue from own sources is imperative to maintaining the pace of fiscal 
consolidation in the state.

14.  Tax Revenue. The government of Assam’s tax–GSDP ratio continues to improve, and 
reached 6.2% in FY2004. In the following 2 years, the tax–GSDP ratio experienced a marginal 
fall due to the impact of the introduction of VAT. However, it has remained higher than in all 
previous years. The government of Assam needs to sustain key reforms in the areas of tax 
administration to improve tax compliance. It is essential for Assam to develop an efficient 
system for managing and administering its own tax revenue in order to benefit from the rise in 
economic activity. Improving own tax yields are important because that will enable Assam to 
obtain some measure of fiscal independence from the central government.  
 
15.  Nontax Revenue. Nontax revenue relative to GSDP, which was close to 1% until 1998–
1999, has also risen continuously and it was estimated at 2.6% of GSDP in FY2006. With 
growing oil prices, ad valorem petroleum royalties will continue to be the largest contributor to 
nontax revenue from economic services; they have been gradually strengthening the nontax 
revenue  share.  Nontax  revenue  has  reasonable  scope  for  augmentation  provided  a  link 
between costs and recoveries is established. Among the social services, medical, public health, 
and  family  welfare  provide  the  largest  share  of  nontax  revenue.  Secondary  education 
contributes most of the fees collected in education.  
 
16.  Dependence on Central Fiscal Transfers. In spite of the continuously improving own-
revenue performance, the dependence of Assam on central transfers has always been large. In 
FY2005, following the recommendations of the TFC, central transfers amounted to 12.8% of 
GSDP, and were estimated at nearly 17.7% of GSDP in FY2006 due to a rise in the share of 
central taxes and a steep rise in the plan grants. 
 
17.  Expenditure. Total government expenditure relative to GSDP may be considered as an 
indicator of the size of government. There was a discernible declining trend in government 
expenditure as a percentage of GSDP in Assam up to FY1998. Since then, there has been an 
increase in total expenditure relative to GSDP. Based on sharp increases in plan assistance, 2 
recent years show significant increases. After falling in the mid-1990s, revenue expenditure 
started rising after FY1996, reaching close to 20% of GSDP in FY1999. It remained roughly at 
this level up until FY2001. There was a small fall in FY2002, it again rose in FY2003 and 
FY2004, before falling again to around 17%–18% in FY2005 and FY2006. Some important 
features on the expenditure side relate to the rising share of committed expenditures such as 
interest payments, pensions, and salaries, and a low and stagnant share of capital expenditure 
in total expenditure. Interest payment peaked at 3.6% of GSDP in FY2002 but since then it has 
fallen based on the softening of the interest rate and relief due to the center’s debt swap 
program. Pensions rose steadily up to FY2004, accounting for 2.43% of GSDP. A reversal in 
this trend is essential for promoting growth and fiscal consolidation, which would in turn require 
sustaining key reforms in areas such as staff rationalization, pension reform, debt restructuring, 
and expenditure management. 
 
18.  Asset-forming government expenditure, such as capital outlay and net lending, steadily 
declined after the mid-1990s but has shown improvement in the current decade. The share of 
capital outlay and loans and advances steadily declined due to a sharp increase in the share of 
repayment obligations of the government of Assam for repayment of loans and advances from 
the central government.  
 
19.  Debt. With regard to the composition of loans, within a span of 6 years (from FY2000 to 
FY2005), the share of market loans in total debt has risen from nearly 23% to 38%, whereas the 
share  of  central  loans  has  fallen  from  64%  in  FY1998  to  25.8%  in  FY2005.  With  the 
recommendation  of  the  TFC  regarding  disintermediation  of  state  loans  by  the  central

6   
government, the states are expected to approach market loan sources and, therefore, central 
loans are expected to have a smaller share in Assam’s debt profile, and most of them will be 
consolidated debt following the TFC’s recommendations. 
 
20.  Public  Sector  Enterprises.  The  PSEs  have  historically  been  a  fiscal  drag  on  the 
government of Assam’s finances. There are 48 PSEs in Assam, of which 33 are corporations, 
eight are cooperatives, and seven are statutory bodies. The PSEs have historically been known 
for  not  keeping  up-to-date  audited  accounts.  For  example,  at  the end  of  March  2004,  no 
information was available for 15 PSEs and there was some information but no audited accounts 
for 14 PSEs. Thus, for 60% of the PSEs, the reliance on available financial information has 
been limited. Of the remaining 19 PSEs, 15 had provisional accounts and there were only four 
PSEs where audited accounts were available. 
 
21.  Fiscal Discipline. The government of Assam has enacted the FRBM Act stipulating 
limitations on the levels of deficit for the state finances, with the targets being 3% fiscal deficit 
and  a  revenue  balance  by  FY2008  following  the  TFC  stipulated  targets.  Accordingly,  the 
government of Assam’s Medium-Term Fiscal Plan (MTFP) presents a fiscal profile that shows a 
revenue  surplus  being  generated  throughout  the  period  from  FY2007  budget  estimates  to 
FY2011 projections. The fiscal deficit relative to GSDP shows a continuous decline from 3.16% 
in FY2007 to 2.28% in FY2011. In both cases, the targets stipulated by the TFC are projected to 
be met. The only features of the MTFP that may cause some concern are that capital outlay as 
a percentage of GSDP is shown to be falling over time and the debt–GSDP ratio has exceeded 
37% of GSDP.  
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
22.  The  issues  faced  in  public  resource  management  in  Assam  are  multifaceted.  An 
assessment of the various aspects of public resource management and the experiences under 
subprogram I have identified that lack of financial flexibility has been impacted by several 
variables.  Key  ones  that  are  relevant  to  the  proposed  subprogram  II  include  (i)  revenue 
administration, (ii) expenditure management, (iii) debt management, and (iv) PSE reforms.  
 
1.  Revenue Administration 
 
23.  In the revenue departments, the first major issue involves the constraint of human 
resources, particularly that of recruitment of operating staff and provision for regular training and 
capacity building of staff. The second issue, related to the first issue, has been the lack of a

practices adopted by what are considered to be more advanced states in India. The third issue

only in terms of the introduction of information and communication technology (ICT) facilities but

specific to major sources of revenue are described below.

2.  Expenditure Management 
 
30.  The key issue in expenditure management is the rising share of committed expenditure 
such as interest payments, pensions, and salaries, and the low and falling share of capital 
expenditure among total expenditure. This is in the context of a situation where Assam, with its 
special  category  state  status.15 Expenditure  on  salaries  and  pensions  is  vulnerable  to  the

  10.  Rationale 
 
44.  Under subprogram I, various reforms were undertaken by the government of Assam to 
improve governance and better manage available resources. Through fiscal reforms, including 
approval of an MTFP and introduction of the FRBM Act, the profile of fiscal imbalances was 
improved and a large revenue deficit has been converted into a surplus in recent years. The 
efforts towards revenue augmentation have included introducing VAT in 2005, broadening the 
tax base, and introducing an ad valorem excise duty structure on IMFL with a consequent 
increase in excise duty collection of 11% in 2006. For increasing revenue collection in areas 
such as VAT, excise duty, motor vehicle tax, and forest produce levies, subprogram I reform 
measures introduced composite checkposts at the main entry and exit points on the trading 
routes with neighboring states, which led to cross-verification of information as well as reduced 
stoppage time for the trucks at the checkposts.  
 
45.  With regard to debt and expenditure, the debt recording and management system was 
put in place, operation and maintenance (O&M) expenditure targets consistent with the updated 
MTFP were approved, and two key MISs were established. Moreover, closure of eight PSEs 
was notified and 50% of the required compensation disbursement for the VRS was paid to 
employees of PSEs identified for closure. 
 
46.  Despite  reforms  attained  under  subprogram  I,  given  the  fiscal  pressure  that  the 
government of Assam is still facing due to an increase in the pension bill and impending 
implementation of the Sixth Pay Commission recommendations, the rationale of subprogram II 
is contained in the urgent need to concentrate on reform initiatives in the areas of (i) increasing 
tax  revenue  via  strengthened  revenue  administration  through  capacity  building  and 
implementation  of  ICT-based  systems;  (ii) improving  expenditure  management  through  the 
gradual introduction of outcome-based budgeting, O&M expenditure estimating, and additional 
closure of loss-generating PSEs; and (iii) developing a centralized debt management system to 
include contingent liabilities. The program reforms will allow greater fiscal space, thus enabling 
the government of Assam to allocate more resources to much-needed social and economic 
infrastructure. This will, in turn, promote private sector investment, thus leading to income 
generation and higher employment. Moreover, given that youth unemployment has historically

13
been a major contributor to social unrest in Assam, creating greater fiscal space will help to 
resolve the unrest problem.  
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
47.  The fiscal reforms embarked upon under subprogram I have put state finances on a 
positive path of increased revenue, controlled expenditure, debt restructuring leading to optimal 
debt servicing costs, and limiting the fiscal drain on state finances of PSEs. The design of 
subprogram II is based on the lessons learned during subprogram I, the current fiscal situation 
in Assam, areas of policy progress where the implementation of policies needs to be pursued, 
and key implementation-oriented actions that will lead to tangible improvements in areas of 
revenue administration, expenditure and debt management, and PSE financial closure.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcomes 
 
48.  The proposed subprogram II is in keeping with national and international experience and 
the government of Assam’s own stated outcomes on good fiscal management in its FRBM Act. 
The impact of subprogram II is to achieve improved financial flexibility of the government of 
Assam through controlled deficits and better fiscal management. It is expected to contribute to 
economic growth through greater investments in social and economic infrastructure, leading to 
employment opportunities and ultimately social peace and harmony.  
 
49.  The policy actions supported by subprogram II will lead to the consolidation of fiscal 
reforms in order to further improve the fiscal position of the government of Assam, as reflected 
in  the  development  policy  letter  and  policy  matrix  (Appendix  5).  The  key  end-of-program 
outcomes will include (i) increased tax revenues as a result of efficient revenue administration; 
(ii) expenditures prioritized to allow greater allocation for investments in, and maintenance of, 
assets;  (iii)  savings  in  debt  servicing  costs as  a  result  of  strengthened  debt management 
capacities and consolidated policy procedures; and (iv) better mitigation of fiscal risk originating 
from selected loss-generating PSEs and further steps towards financial closure and initiation of 
the legal closure process for PSEs notified for closure by getting the statutory audits completed 
and initiating liquidation of assets.  
 
50.  These outcomes will be reflected in, and monitored through, 
 
(i)  continued  adherence  to  deficit  targets  prescribed  in  the  FRBM  Act  beyond 
FY2008, and possibly a surplus on the revenue account; 
(ii)  progressively improving own revenue–GSDP ratio; 
(iii)  progressively increasing investments in assets as a percentage of GSDP; 
(iv)  stable debt servicing cost to GSDP ratio; and  
(v)  progressively  reducing  budgetary  support  for  PSEs  and  reduced  contingent 
liabilities  on  account  of  guarantees  issued  by  the  government  of  Assam  for

89.  ADB affirms that corrupt behavior is a serious hindrance to the development process. It 
rejects the argument that corruption’s beneficial effects outweigh its negative consequences, or 
that it is inappropriate for international financial institutions to address such issues. ADB notes 
that  experience  drawn from  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region  and  elsewhere  demonstrates  that 
significant progress can be made against corruption if the proper legal, institutional, and policy 
reforms are in place. ADB welcomes the growing focus upon anticorruption issues as part of its 
broader  effort  to  advance  the  principles  of  transparency,  predictability,  accountability,  and 
participation under its governance policy. At the broadest level, ADB’s stance on anticorruption 
issues is intended to reduce the burden that widespread, systemic corruption exacts upon the 
economies  of  the  region  and  the  development  of  ADB’s  developing  member  countries.  In 
keeping with Article 36(2) of the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank,44 ADB 
initiatives  regarding  corruption  will  be  grounded  solely  upon  economic  considerations  and 
concerns of sound development management. They will not involve interference in the political 
affairs of a developing member country or be influenced by its political character.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Expected Benefits 
 
100.  The program loan will help improve revenue administration, and strengthen expenditure 
management and debt management of the government of Assam, thus enabling it to create 
greater  fiscal  space.  The  benefits  of  subprogram  II  are  expected  to  be  evident  in  (i)  the 
availability of more resources to invest in social and economic infrastructure in the state, which 
should ultimately assist in enhancing the welfare of the poor in the rural hinterlands; (ii) more 
efficient  allocation  of  budget  resources  based  on  outcomes  sought  rather  than  on  an 
incremental and ad hoc manner; and (iii) the ability of the government of Assam, in the long 
term, to place its fiscal affairs on a sounder footing that can sustain investments for more rapid 
and inclusive growth.  
 
101.  The point on inclusive growth is critical to the state if it is to deal effectively with the 
social marginalization that exists currently. Specific benefits of subprogram II can be outlined as 
follows: 
 
(i)  greater consideration of outcomes in resource allocations; 
(ii)  better pension management for the employees of the state government; 
(iii)  simplified administrative and procedural requirements (e.g., filing requirements 
under the VAT Act);  
(iv)  more streamlined tax administration and engagement with large taxpayers; 
(v)  greater transparency and increased revenues, as a result of auctions of specific 
licenses;  
(vi)  more objective valuation of fixed public assets, and a sustainable system of 
maintenance of such assets; 
(vii)  more effective use of technology to manage administrative processes (such as 
through an upgraded TIMS and computerization of property records); 
(viii)  greater transparency in state affairs, such as on contingent liabilities; and 
(ix)  reduced long-term burden on the government of Assam to support PSEs through 
application of a VRS and consequent retraining schemes for employees. 
 
102.  As subprogram II seeks to strengthen state fiscal affairs, there should be a direct impact 
on the economic growth rate of the state, which currently lags behind the national average. A 
higher growth rate and greater GSDP level will mean that the entire public will eventually benefit 
from subprogram II. The impact of subprogram II will also be felt in the medium term by the poor 
in the rural hinterlands. Subprogram II should create opportunities for the state government to 
invest in much-needed infrastructure that will allow the broader state economy to be better 
integrated. To date, and to some extent, the remnants of the insurgency problem in the state 
have  been  a  function  of  the  inability  of  the  state  to  bring  about  inclusive  and  integrated 
development. A summary poverty reduction analysis is presented in Appendix 12. 
 
B.  Risks and Safeguards 
 
103.  Subprogram II’s success depends on the government of Assam’s continuing strong 
commitment to fiscal reforms and to the broader governance issues of transparency in fiscal 
matters.  There  are  some  slight  risks  that  current  measures  and  reform  efforts,  including 
insufficient  capacity  in  specific  implementing  government  agencies,  may  not  be  sustained. 
These risks will be mitigated by (i) continued policy dialogue with the government of Assam and 
other  stakeholders  in  Assam  (such  as  business  associations),  and  (ii)  specific  technical

27
assistance  and  capacity-development  support.  For  its  part,  the  government  of  Assam  has 
expressed its commitment in the budget speech to pursue the reforms sought by subprogram II, 
and the level of engagement in the program design has been substantive. The economic and 
social outcomes of policies adopted and actions taken under subprogram II are unlikely to have 
adverse environmental impacts. 
 
104.  The assumptions inherent in subprogram II are that (i) the government of Assam’s 
commitments to reforms across the various sectors (including PSEs) will remain high during the 
program implementation period, (ii) existing central policies that are favorable to the state will 
continue to be in place in the medium to long term, (iii) any political developments that take 
place in the short-to-medium term do not adversely affect subprogram II in any substantive 
manner, and (iv) the greater fiscal space will result in the reorientation of expenditure into social 
and economic infrastructure. The three main areas of risks that are likely to arise and impact on 
subprogram II are (i) weaknesses in the institutional capacity of relevant government agencies, 
(ii) fiduciary risks relating to the use of loan proceeds, and (iii) external risks relating to inflation 
and flooding.    
 
(i)  Institutional  Capacity.  Implementing  subprogram  II  will  place  additional 
demands on the institutional capacities of government agencies (in terms of use 
of staff time, for example) that are executing and implementing it. Certain reforms 
under subprogram II will also require skills and experience that are not currently 
available in the relevant government agencies. These include (a) implementation 
of OBB, and (b) implementation of VRS compensation to employees of PSEs 
notified for closure. Close performance monitoring and targeted TA (as specified 
in  Supplementary  Appendix  D)  to  the  relevant  agencies  will  help  mitigate 
implementation delays due to capacity constraints. 
(ii)  Fiduciary Risks. Fiduciary risks in subprogram II could arise in two possible 
ways.  First,  there  is  a  generic  risk  that  funds  might  not  be  applied  for  the 
purposes intended. To first mitigate this risk, assurances have been sought from 
the government of Assam that counterpart funds will be applied for program 
purposes. This includes requiring the application of counterpart funds to VRS 
compensation for employees of PSEs notified for closure and to the government 
of Assam’s contribution to the defined contribution pension scheme. Second, the 
government of Assam will be required to provide quarterly progress reports to 
ADB. Regular monitoring of this commitment by ADB will be done as part of 
program implementation.  
(iii)  External Risks. (a) The all-India consumer price index increased from 3.0% in 
FY2005 to 5.1% in FY2006. At the end of March 2008, the year-on-year inflation 
was 7.4%.45 However, there seems to be upward pressure on the global prices of 
wheat (which increased by 88% between April 2000 and January 2008) and rice 
(which  increased  by  15%  in  the  same  period).  These  trends  are  no  doubt 
inflationary and there is resultant pressure on the domestic prices of these food 
articles. Since the major expenditure of the poor is on food, the income surplus of 
the poor and the net of food consumption are most probably reduced, thus 
impacting the consumption of nonfood items. The inflation rate in India in mid-
2008 crossed to 11%, and the Indian economy is showing signs of slowing. This 
may  have  a  negative  impact  on  the  collection  of  revenue  at  the  central 
government  level  and  consequently  on  the  central  transfers  to  Assam  that

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Background and Recent Performance 
 
1.  The Economy 
 
1.  Several structural features have historically constrained the economic performance of 
Assam.  Its  problems  have  been  those  of  remoteness,  partially  hilly  terrain,  and  high 
transportation costs. The low-income plains regions are also constrained by high population 
density, a large but slow-growing agriculture sector, and a high incidence of poverty. In the 
1990s insurgency considerably slowed economic activity in Assam. The gross state domestic 
product (GSDP) growth at constant prices from FY1993 to FY1999 was below 2% on a trend 
basis. With the decline in insurgency in recent years, and some strong tax incentives introduced 
by  the  central  government,  the  manufacturing  and  sectors  showed  buoyant  growth  during 
FY1999 to FY2005, with manufacturing growing at 8.6% per annum and services growing at 
8.0%. Led by this growth, the GSDP trend growth rate was 5.4%. The primary sector growth 
rate, although higher than the previous period trend growth rate, was still close to 1%.  
 
2.  In terms of compositional changes, the relatively low growth rates of agriculture and the 
primary sector as a whole have led to a fall in its share among whole sectors, whereas the 
share of the services sector has steadily increased. The share of the primary sector fell from a 
level of nearly 47% to 34 %, a fall of 13 percentage points, amounting to nearly one percentage 
point per year during FY1993 to FY2005. Correspondingly, the share of the tertiary sector has 
increased from 38.2% to 49.5%. A significant portion of the services sector comprises trade, 
hotels and restaurants, and public administration. The increase in the share of the secondary 
sector has been much less, from 14.9% in FY1993 to 17.4% in FY2005. 
 
2.  Fiscal Performance 
 
3.  Against the background of the poorly performing state economy during the 1990s, the 
finances of the government of Assam underwent a major crisis in the late 1990s with the 
revenue deficit and fiscal deficit reaching alarming levels. In FY1999, the revenue deficit relative 
to GSDP rose to 3.4% of GSDP, having been in surplus in the 3 preceding years. State finances 
remained in revenue deficit until FY2004. The fiscal deficit was close to 5% of GSDP in FY2001, 
and it remained high until FY2004. It was due to a substantial increase in fiscal transfers that, in 
FY2005, a revenue surplus and even a small fiscal surplus was recorded. However, in FY2006, 
revenue deficit was recorded once again.

4.  Although Assam was recognized as a special category state in the Fourth Five-Year 
Plan, it was given the benefit of 90:10 grant-loan composition of plan assistance, effective from 
April 1990. It may be noted that the revenue deficit of a special category state is not comparable 
to the general category states because the revenue receipts of the former include 90% of plan 
assistance given as grants, a significant proportion of which is meant for capital expenditure. 
Thus, the true picture was far more serious than what was indicated by the budget accounts. 
 
5.  In explaining the development of the fiscal crisis in the late 1990s, it is notable that 
Assam's finances were exposed to at least four external shocks beyond the control of the 
government of Assam. First was the revision of salaries and pensions of central government 
employees and the subsequent near-convergence of pay scales and other allowances between 
the center and the states including Assam. Secondly, there was a fall in the central tax-GDP 
ratio by nearly two percentage points during the 1990s, leading to a fall in the states’ share of 
central taxes. Thirdly, the revenue from forests in Assam, which at one time was a mainstay of 
Assam's nontax resources, deteriorated sharply after the Supreme Court judgment banning 
felling of trees unless done according to scientific plans. Fourthly, interest rates have risen 
sharply since the mid-1990s, especially on small savings and central loans.  
 
6.  These external pressures worked in combination with critical internal weaknesses, which 
were due to (i) a rise in insurgency affecting economic as well as fiscal performance, (ii) slow 
industrial growth, (iii) the dismal performance of state public sector enterprises (PSEs), and (iv) 
a high salary burden linked to excessive employment in government. The basic mismatch in 
Assam's fiscal position was reflected in the ways and means problem.1 In the crisis period, 
Assam topped the list of states for the number of days in a year for which payments were 
suspended from the treasury. The state had continuing ways and means problems for several 
years and regularly ran an overdraft with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).  
 
7.  Just as the onset of the fiscal crisis had extraneous causes, part of the explanation for 
the beginning of recovery was also due to external factors. The reason for the improvement in 
FY2005  was  higher  transfers  following  the  recommendations  of  the  Twelfth  Finance 
Commission (TFC). This was combined with much higher central tax revenue, which helped 
increase the resource transfer from the center. A revenue surplus was recorded in FY2005 after 
a long gap. Among the internal factors, two are critically important: (i) Assam enacted fiscal 
responsibility legislation, and (ii) it implemented the value-added tax (VAT) regime. 
 
3.  Resource Mobilization 
 
8.  While the profile of fiscal imbalance provides a summary indication of the position of 
state  finances,  it  is  also  an  indicator  of  revenue  performance  against  expenditure  trends. 
Revenue performance, in turn, is a combination of the state’s collection of own-tax revenues, 
nontax revenues, and transfers from the center. The state’s own revenue, inclusive of both tax 
and nontax revenues, increased at a trend annual growth rate of 14.46% between FY1993 and 
FY2005, which was nearly four percentage points higher than the transfers from the center, the 
highest growth being in state tax revenues.

5.  Nontax Revenue 
 
11.  Nontax revenue relative to GSDP, which was close to 1% until FY1998, also rose 
continuously and is estimated to be 2.6% of GSDP in FY2006. The government of Assam's 
nontax revenue arises from its ownership of assets and its role as a provider of services. There 
are  six  main  sources  of  nontax  revenue  in  Assam:  royalty  on  minerals,  interest  receipts, 
dividends, and receipts from general, social, and economic services. In each case, there is a 
relationship between nontax revenue and a corresponding base, consisting of past investments 
and current expenditure. Thus, interest receipts relate to outstanding loans extended by the 
government, dividends to the outstanding equity investment, and returns from services to past 
investments in building assets for providing these services (schools, hospitals, irrigation canals, 
government buildings, etc.) and current expenditure on these services.  
 
12.  The government of Assam’s nontax revenue accounted for nearly 36% of own revenue 
in FY1993. This contribution steadily declined to 25.5% in FY2001. After this, once again, there 
has been an improvement in its share relative to GSDP. The improvement after FY2001 has 
arisen mainly out of revisions of royalty rates by the central government. Like tax revenue, 
nontax revenue also shows considerable volatility as indicated by the annual growth rates. 
Royalty on minerals is the major source of nontax revenue for the government of Assam. The 
relative importance of forestry has receded significantly following the decision of the Supreme 
Court to ban felling of tress except under suitable scientific plans. It has been highlighted in

6.  Central Transfers 
 
14.  There are two main components of central transfers: the share in central taxes and in 
central grants. In FY1997 these transfers amounted to 13.43% of GSDP, but they had fallen to 
10.84% by FY1999. With the award of the Eleventh Finance Commission, central transfers rose 
to 11.8% in FY2000. In FY2004, these rose further to 14.05% of GSDP based on a rise in plan 
grants.  In  FY2005,  following  the  recommendations  of  the  Twelfth  Finance  Commission, 
transfers amounted to 12.8% and are estimated at nearly 17.7% in FY2006, which is due to a 
rise in the share of central taxes and a steep rise in plan grants.  
 
15.  The  government  of  Assam  finances  are  highly  sensitive  to  changes  in  central  tax 
revenue  because  the  tax  devolution  constitutes  a  significant  share  of  the  state's  total  tax 
revenue. While the share of central taxes increased from 38.5% in FY1993 to 48% in FY1997, 
there was subsequently a steady decline. This corresponded to the increasing importance of 
plan grants in total transfers; in FY2006, plan grants were estimated at 56% of total transfers. 
The share of central transfers in total revenue receipts has fallen from a peak of 72% in FY1996 
to  nearly  61%  in  FY2005.  Given  that  central  transfers  have  increased  in  this  period,  the 
decrease in relative proportion does not reflect a fall in central transfers. It reflects the fact that 
Assam’s own revenues have grown even faster. It is a healthy trend that Assam’s own tax 
revenue, after being lower than its share in central tax revenue, has exceeded central tax 
revenue in 3 recent years (FY2002, FY2004, and FY2005). This indicates that Assam’s tax 
buoyancy has improved beyond that of the central tax revenue in recent years.  
 
16.  Although there has been a decline in the share of central transfers, the dependence of 
Assam on central transfers continues to be high. The recovery in recent years therefore has had 
strong support due to a rise in both own revenue and central transfers.

10.  Fiscal Management Reform Path 
 
28.  The government of Assam enacted the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management 
(FRBM) Act in May 2005. It was amended in September 2005 and again in August 2007. With 
these amendments, the FRBM Act has provided for meeting all the conditions for claiming debt 
relief as provided by the TFC. The following are the main provisions of the FRBM Act: 
 
(i)  Lowering the revenue deficit to zero by FY2008. With the latest amendment, it is 
further stipulated that the revenue deficit will be reduced annually at a rate that is 
consistent with achieving the target of zero revenue deficit by FY2008. 
(ii)  Lowering the fiscal deficit to 3% of GSDP by FY2008. Further, fiscal deficit will be 
reduced annually in a manner consistent with achieving the 3% target of GSDP 
by FY2008. 
(iii)  Restricting the total debt stock, including debt in respect of which the government 
of Assam may have extended guarantees, to 45% of GSDP by FY2009. 
 
29.  In respect of outstanding guarantees for debt raised by various PSEs, cooperatives, and 
autonomous bodies, these will be subject to the limit determined by 50% of the state’s tax and 
nontax  revenue  of  the  second  preceding  year  consistent  with  the  figures  of  the  finance 
accounts. This stipulation, provided for in the latest amendment, changes the original provision 
where reference was only to the previous year, and an alternative condition of 5% of GSDP of 
the previous year was also provided.  
 
30.  The latest amendment has also provided that in the annual budget, a detailed statement 
giving the number of employees in government, public sector, and aided institutions, and related 
salaries, will be provided. 
 
31.  With these provisions, the FRBM Act of the government of Assam now meets all the 
TFC stipulations for getting debt relief subject to actual improvement in reducing revenue deficit. 
It is understood that the government of Assam’s debt to central government, outstanding as of 
31 March 2004, has already been consolidated and rescheduled for 20 years, as recommended 
by the TFC. The government of Assam now has to ensure that it takes maximum advantage of 
the write-off provisions linked to any reduction in revenue deficit.

2.  The broader political economy of Assam is characterized by, among other things, (i)

resources (more than 60% of state revenue receipts). 
 
2.  Public Service and Public Sector Enterprises 
 
3.  The  level  of  government  employment  in  Assam  is  now  considered  to  be  fiscally

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The core focus of the Asian Development Bank's (ADB’s) operational strategy in India is poverty reduction 
through infrastructure-led growth. ADB’s current operational strategy for India was laid down in the country 
strategy and program 2003a—with updates in 2004 and 2005—and the country operations business planb in 2006 
to reflect the evolving priorities of the Government of India. The three pillars of ADB’s strategy are inclusive and 
broad-based growth, social development, and good governance. The country strategy and program for India 
mainstreams poverty reduction through growth as the central goal of ADB operations in India.  
 
India’s 11th Five Year Plan (FY2007–FY2011) envisages a new growth paradigm that will be much more broad-
based and inclusive, bringing about a faster reduction in poverty. It focuses on policies and investment plans that 
support (i) inclusive growth, with particular emphasis on agriculture and rural development and raising investment 
in infrastructure; (ii) improvement in the quality and delivery of public services; (iii) creation of investment and 
employment opportunities, especially in rural areas; and (iv) strengthening of infrastructure.  
 
In addition to achieving progress in sector areas, the 11th Five Year Plan also aims to foster good governance by 
extending access to essential public services (such as health, education, clean drinking water, and sanitation) to 
those  who  are  deprived  of  them,  improving  government  capacity,  promoting  local  government,  tackling 
corruption, enhancing access to justice for the poor, and improving security and public order. This is to be 
complemented by fostering partnerships between government, the private sector, and civil society organizations 
in order to improve service delivery.  
 
ADB’s country strategy and program aims to assist good governance. It will address key governance issues on a 
sector and thematic basis, and will hence play a key role in supporting policy and institutional reforms to improve 
sector governance and increase sector efficiency (e.g., in energy, transport, education, urban health and urban 
water  supply,  and  sanitation  sectors).  The  Assam  Governance  and  Public  Resource  Management  Sector 
Development Program, in turn, aims to address the weaknesses in quality and delivery of services by orienting 
the government of Assam towards a more results-oriented culture. It also stresses resource allocation both for 
investment and for proper maintenance of assets.

The link between investment and growth is well established. Given the orientation of the government to make
